item.description: Email: moshepol[at]mit[dot]edu Twitter LinkedIn Fun Fact: Some words are regular travelers, going on vacation abroad and returning with a new accent. Consider the Arabic dār al-ṣināʿa (literally, house of manufacture; a factory). It was borrowed into Latin around the middle of the previous millenium as arsana, eventually becoming the word we know in English as arsenal. item.title: Moshe Poliak
item.description: I am a PhD student in Brain and Cognitive Sciences at MIT. I study psycholinguistics, or what processes in the mind are involed in language production and comprehension. Specifically, I care about how we use non-literal properties of language to make better sense of the linguistic input and to produce clearer linguistic output.
